Breaking down my Top Ten Changeups in baseball right now. 

1️⃣ Devin Williams

When it comes to a changeup, this one immediately comes to mind. A absolutely devastating and unique pitches in all of baseball. Let’s not forget, this dude can pitch. Posting a 1.93 ERA in ‘22 mixed with 96 K’s 60.2 innings.

Changeup Numbers:

🛸 58.1% Usage 🥹
🛸 83.4 Average Velo (FB at 93.9)
🛸 43.9% WHIFF
🛸 2739 Average SpinR
🛸 3:15 Spin Direction / 3:30 Observed
🛸 .185 BAA in ‘22
🛸 .161 BAA in ‘21

One of the best individual pitches over the last decade.

His 19 inches of run is 24% higher than the average pitchers with similar velo & release. Let’s not forget the 42.7 inches of drop.

The Airbender takes the crown. 

What are your thoughts on the list? 

🤙

#baseball #pitching #changeup #mlb

Baseball’s best pitchers play catch with their Changeup regularly.

Here’s some quick Changeup catch advice ✅💡

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it!

We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count.

Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet.  We even see it with these Stroman videos and how the ball dies!

BUT, when you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont make it to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers.

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

Regardless of distance, throw your Changeup consecutively and alternate between the FB too!

🤙

Breaking down my Top Ten Sliders in baseball right now. 💪

🔟 Andrew Chafin

The slider has been a nightmare of a pitch for hitters when facing Andrew Chafin. A gyro slider that disappears as it gets to the plate. A solid 2022 campaign posting a 2.83 in 57.1 innings.

Slider Numbers:

⚡️ 31.9% Usage 🥹
⚡️ 82.9 Average Velo (FB at 91.6)
⚡️ 60.4% WHIFF
⚡️ 2485 Average SpinR
⚡️ 5:30 Spin Direction (19% efficiency)
⚡️ .085 BAA in ‘22
⚡️ .092 BAA in ‘21

“I hold a curveball grip, throw it as hard as I can, and it comes out a slider. So, is it a curveball or a slider? I guess whatever it does is what it is. Really, I don’t care what people call it as long as the hitters swing and miss. If that happens, I’m happy.”

An underrated pitcher that starts off this filthy list!

Who’s next?

🤙

Breaking down my Top Ten Sliders in baseball right now. 💪

9️⃣ Adam Ottavino

Let’s chat about one of the slurviest sliders in the game. Another solid season for Adam with a WHIP under 1 and ERA of 2.06 (xERA of 2.35) in 65.2 innings.

Slider Numbers:

⚡️ 42.9% Usage
⚡️ 81 Average Velo (FB at 94.8)
⚡️ 38.4% WHIFF
⚡️ 2700 Average SpinR
⚡️ 8:15 Spin Direction (65% efficiency)
⚡️ .165 BAA in ‘22
⚡️ 17.7 inches - average horizontal movement
⚡️ 50/79 K’s on the Slider

I remember watching Ottavino and dropping my jaw on some of his sliders over the years. He mentions a big key for him is feeling the hand on the side and tinkering with hand position depending on what he wants the pitch to do.

“What I basically developed was that kind of horizontal-breaking slider. The good thing about it is that it doesn’t hump up, because it starts kind of neutral. That was the genesis of the pitch. Over time, I’ve definitely tinkered with it a lot.”

Who’s next?

🤙

Cease has one of baseball’s top sliders. There’s no question about that! 💪

⚡️ 2833 Average Spin 
🕣 8:45 Spin Direction

The Grip: Tight grip with thumb up on the ball rather than underneath. Interesting enough, he doesn’t try to supinate or any wrist manipulation. 

Cease keeps it simple. Allows the grip to work and throws it hard through his target and stays relaxed!

Could the increase use in his slider attribute to the best season of his career?

Usage Increase: +12.3%

Potentially. There are a lot of variables, such as situations & pitch selection in specific counts and hitters, that attributed to a Cy Young Finalist season but we can see that the slider played a huge role.

Who’s taking the crown? 👑

1️⃣ Jacob deGrom

Maybe this was no surprise but this slider has the numbers to back it up.

One of baseball’s best pitchers over the last decade, deGrom has been touted as the 🐐 or even “The best I’ve seen” by current and former big leaguers. The slider is so good, I had to show what it’s done his last 26 starts.

Last 26 starts:
🐐 2.08 ERA (1.08 in ‘21)
🐐 248 K’s and 19 walks 🤯

Slider Numbers:

⚡️ 36.35% Usage in the last 26 starts
⚡️ 92.6 Average Velo
⚡️ 55.6% Whiff in last 26 starts
⚡️ 2589 Average SpinR
⚡️ .117 BAA in last 26 starts
⚡️ 129/248 K’s on the Slider in last 26 starts
⚡️ xBAA in ‘22: .141
⚡️ xBAA in ‘21: .102
⚡️ 11:45 Spin (34% efficiency)

The exact definition of a last second turn on a slider. It’s not fair. Over and over we preach arm speed and hand speed, especially on the slider. Everyone on this list does this creating deception with one of baseball’s best pitches.

deGrom goes to a new home where he will take this slider with him.

What pitch would you like to see next for the Top Ten?

🤙

Looking at how the legs become a key part of our mechanics. We all move different but the general idea of the lower half’s engagement has become universally a positive idea! Such as being in a athletic and power position as we move down the mound! 💪

I see a lot of guys create a “pushing” feel off the mound and lose ALL of the energy created from the peak of the leg kick to that beginning drift down the mound as our back foot remains in the ground!

There’s no need to catapult and force the arm to go too soon causing us to release early or even late. The 💡 turns on for a lot of guys when they feel that hinge and tension in the hip.

I like the movement of the pitcher’s glutes and hips to move out as the drift down the mound begins. You can see that in the video from @movement_is_medicine where he’s in a similar movement of a deadlift after he catches the ball. But promotes being in a athletic power position! 💪 This gives us a great feel to not get so jumpy and maintain force into the ground as we create our power!

Just a reminder, this will not look the same for everyone!

But this can aid into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

Guys that have a effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the core ➡️ hips ➡️ legs.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 💪

This is super interesting, and in the same category of a cue I’m looking into like front side extension that also may not look the same for everyone.

The legs are our strongest parts of our body, so we have to use them! 🤙

#baseball #pitching #pitchingmechanics #losangeles #changeupuniversity

Q: “Why do I need a Changeup?”

A: The idea behind having another pitch in your arsenal is to get the hitter off balance to get them out.

Some may disagree with me but I’ve always been a believer in having a secondary pitch that moves arm side and one the moves glove side. Of course, a fastball too (4 seam, 2 seam, 1 seam, or sinker).

When it comes to the Changeup, too many young arms give up on it too soon.

I asked a player not too long ago while I was playing catch with him, 

“Throw me your Changeup”
“I don’t have one”

Right then in there we focused on the Changeup and by the end of the catch play, he had a pretty decent one.

We think there is one way to throw it and if we don’t throw one like a grip we saw on YouTube or whichever, it can’t be useful. That’s false. We all use different grips based on our arm angle, strength, hand size etc…

Your time is now to get a Changeup. It is never too early or too late. Having a deceptive pitch that looks like a fastball until the last second will make you a dangerous pitcher.

DON’T FORGET! Throw it everyday! Just because it isn’t “on” or you lost it doesn’t mean we should shy away from it. Throw it, a lot!

#baseball #pitching #mlb #changeupuniversity

Breaking down my Top 12 Curveballs in baseball right now. Why 12? Honoring 12-6 breaking balls. 😬

1️⃣ Lance McCullers Jr.

“One of the most lethal pitches in the game today” - Sports Illustrated 

The top curveball right now. But why?

Let’s dive into it.

LMJ. One of the spin revolution pioneers. The one who threw 24 straight knuckle curveballs to send his team to the World Series.

Lance is 1 of 2 pitchers to finish in the Top 20 in RV/100 the last two seasons with the Curve.

I’ve placed his ranking next to his stats.

Curveball Numbers:

⚡️ RV/100: -2.9 (#2 in MLB)
⚡️ 24.9% Usage in ‘22
⚡️ 82.7 Average Velo
⚡️ 37.2% Whiff
⚡️ 3013 Average SpinR (#8 in MLB)
⚡️ .116 BAA in ‘22 (#2 in MLB)
⚡️ .170 BAA in career vs Curveball
⚡️ 7:45 Spin Direction
⚡️ +8% drop vs the average
⚡️ +49% break vs the average

With the FB/CH combo, it makes life much more difficult for hitters.

This first split shot shows that.

Deception out of the hand and it’s trajectory until it’s too late and the hitter has made the decision to swing. The Changeup is already out of the hitting zone or coming back into it.

This is why understanding your pitches and how they tunnel one another makes you extremely effective even if you can’t throw 95+.

The Changeup, more so than a lot of offspeed, seems to be the most effective pitch to tunnel off of our fastball. Closely followed by a slider and other late moving off speed pitches.

How can I tunnel my Changeup off of my fastball? 🤔

This starts with establishing feel for your Changeup and the grip. From there, we then analyze HOW your pitch is moving and what needs to occur to make it better and feed off the fastball.

This attributes to maintaining the same arm speed and wrist positions for deception.

The analytics and numbers are just added variables to help design our Changeup the way we see effective. Does the eye test work in developing our Changeup to be effective? For sure, but it also only tells us part of the story. The analysis comes into play when we are seeing consistent lift, backspin & velocity making our Changeup ineffective. The analytics allow us to slow things down and see where we can make some adjustments.

All, help us achieve the goal of creating swings and misses or weak contact with our Changeup.

Having this combo makes you a very dangerous pitcher! 🤙

Baseball’s best pitchers play catch with their Changeup regularly.

Here’s some quick Changeup catch advice ✅💡

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it!

We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count.

Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet.  We even see it with these two and how the ball dies!

BUT, when you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont make it to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers.

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

Regardless of distance, throw your Changeup consecutively and alternate between the FB too!

🤙

A pretty interesting correlation I have seen with a few of my athletes with their Changeup has been pinky position.

Now, many pitchers have success with their pinky being under the ball in their Changeup, so no need to change anything.

BUT, for those who are noticing their Changeup having a lack of grip, movement and control try this out.

Is your Changeup always going up and in or way inside? 

All arm side? No control?

I have noticed that the ball tends to slip out of our hand at release without the proper control and the ball is running off of our middle and ring fingers too early. Hint why the ball jumps out arm side (Slide 3).

A quick adjustment I have my athletes do it moving their pinky up on the ball. This transition has been extremely successful since that pinky now allows the ball to stay on with our proper fingers to release at the time we want + thumb under the ball for control.

This small adjustments changes how we get inside the ball to aid in tilted spin direction which will help our CH have deception!

Continue to maintain consistent arm speed with your FB for added deception and effectiveness! 🔑

I’ve been getting asked a lot, how do I become more loose or effortless? 🤔

We can sit here and say, do this drill or throw this light ball hard and blah blah blah BUT are we ignoring the obvious?

Maybe, just maybe, the athlete needs to stretch more and focus on the not so attractive mobility work? 98.5% of the time, yes. We are simply too tight. Not enough stretching after working out or even tensing up to throw harder which actually limits your ROM with the muscles tensing.

So, how is the effortless throwing created though? A large part comes down to the flexibility and mobility in that lower half so that we can use our strength to its most efficient point. Like I mentioned above, those two things are 🔑.

Check out in these videos how the pitcher’s glutes and hips move out as they begin to ride the slide. Similar movement to a deadlift to activate the posterior chain.

This allows us to get into our glutes where our power is generated. This is where our core activates and prepares the body for the energy to be translated from down the hill into rotation. 

Our goal as we release the ball is to make it effortless. The arm acts as a slingshot. Think of the slingshot, the legs are when you pull back as power/energy is created. The letting go part translates to FFS and the motion forward is the rotating of the hips and release of the baseball.

This turns into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

These guys all have that effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the legs ➡️ hips ➡️ core.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 

Our goal is to create HEALTHY pitchers and athletes simultaneously!

Working on throwing a slider? 🤔

One of the biggest things is finding a spot on the ball that is comfortable where you can pull on a seam.

The problem that I see with many pitchers learning to throw the slider is they tend to stay on top of the ball, behind it or we drop our elbow and basically start under the ball which will 1. make it harder with shorter break (aka a cutter) and 2. make it what we call a ‘spinner’ where it just spins but stay on a straightened plane. This also known as a backup breaking ball. Supposed to break but doesn’t.

Like in these images/videos, we have to find a way to get our fingers on the side of the ball to aid in creating side spin that is close to side spin direction. Opposite of Changeup!

The spin will create more life and slide like movement on the pitch that makes it look like a fastball until it slides off the table. Hint why it is called a slider.

Practice getting on the side of the ball in catch play and bullpens to create that feel and consistency.

When I throw it, I try to pull on the seam as hard as I can as well as stay on the side of the ball.

Keys to the slider:

🔑Throw it hard, quick hand speed

🔑Same mechanics + arm angle

🔑Hand on the side of the ball with fingertips slightly coming over the top so we get a little topspin and don’t just throw spinners

🔑Find a part of the ball where it is easiest for you to pull

A mechanical issue I see when learning a new breaking pitch is we try to force the spin and movement by over rotating and opening up our shoulders way too early.

This will cause us to create a spinner and prevents us from controlling the pitch. We will often miss arm side when we do this, not just on the slider but on all pitches.

It’s effective to both sides of the plate when we can spin it in for a strike in ANY count. Similar to our Changeup. Locating 3+ pitches will make you a very very very dangerous pitcher.

I’ll be diving into this more with the @rapsodobaseball ⚡️

Why do we want our middle finger away from the center of the ball? 🧐

Nolan Ryan explains what I call “Middle Finger Misdirection” 🚂

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

As the ring finger slips off the ball, the inside part of the middle finger pulls and changes the axis of the ball! 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Now, when it comes to velocity differs from your fastball, Nolan Ryan says 10-15 off. That is very tough to do. I would start by trying to be 5-7 off then gradually decrease the velo as you gain more and more feel for it!

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

Looking at how the legs become a key part of our mechanics. We all move different but the general idea of the lower half’s engagement has become universally a positive idea! Such as being in a athletic and power position as we move down the mound! 💪

Trailside stacking is so important to maintain athleticism and power through our mechanics. This is where we can almost create a line from our ankle, knee, hip, and shoulder.

I see a lot of guys create a “pushing” feel off the mound and lose ALL of the energy created from the peak of the leg kick to that beginning drift down the mound as our back foot remains in the ground!

There’s no need to catapult and force the arm to go too soon causing us to release early or even late. The 💡 turns on for a lot of guys when they feel that hinge and tension in the hip.

Just a reminder, this will not look the same for everyone!

But this can aid into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

Guys that have a effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the core ➡️ hips ➡️ legs.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 💪

The legs are our strongest parts of our body, so we have to use them! 🤙 - @cnpitching

I’ve always been a big advocate for longer catch play.

Does that necessarily mean more throws? No.

But it certainly means more focus and more intent. We see over and over at the high school and college level of abbreviated catch sessions - mainly for pitchers/PO’s.

This becomes a “time” issue during a practice at those levels, when in reality, they hit BP for 75% of the that time.

It’s a joke and we need to appreciate and embrace playing catch with a purpose to prepare our bodies and minds. Each throw needs a focus whether it’s a breaking ball, Changeup or simply just hitting your partner’s glove.

We need PURPOSE. Robbing these young arms from finding that just to get to batting practice…

Carve out 20-30 minutes for CATCH in practice. Not stretching mixed with catch play.

Take your time between throws and focus. This is YOUR BP as a pitcher.

There are so many frustrating moments when it comes to developing and learning a Changeup.

We ask ourselves so many questions...

💥How should I grip it?
💥How often should I throw it?
💥Why isn’t it moving the way I want it to?
💥Why am I not confident in throwing a Changeup?

We all ask these questions. Especially if we are later in our career and development finding multiple excuses to not throw one.

It’s a extremely difficult pitch to master.

Slide 1 shows 2025 grad @huntertarchalski Changeup we’ve been working on where we shifted his middle finger away from the center and more to the inside of the ball. Interesting enough his changeup gets great velocity differential vs his fastball which sits around 80-82 during his first 3 pens after the off-season.

We played with some grips today and I wanted to show what happens when our middle finger stays in the center of the ball in slide 2.

Aside from the grip, mechanics play a key role to making sure we aren’t late and supinated our arm to create more breaking ball like movement.

I’m having a blast playing with @rapsodobaseball Insight Camera and Pitching 2.0 unit! 💪🔥

The biggest things when developing a Changeup:

✅Comfort // You’ve developed a feel and comfortability with your grip so you can throw it with repetition.

✅Arm Speed // Throwing it hard to mirror your fastball and other offspeed pitches to create deception. Last thing we want to do it tip our pitches.

✅Fingers // Allow the fingers to manipulate the ball to create movement and drop in velo. This starts with taking the strongest finger (middle) away from the center of the ball and finding a way to get the ring finger on top of the ball as we release the pitch. A much weaker finger.

✅Throw it // Throw your Changeup a lot. Catch play is a huge moment where we establish feel. Many of the big leaguers I speak with about the Changeup throw it EVERYDAY. Long toss. Flat ground. Bullpen. Throw it often. We should do this with our other pitches as well. (I’d suggest not throwing long toss with breaking balls) 🤙

A concept I’ve been preaching over and over is the ability for both, index and middle fingers, to release the ball simultaneously.

Why?

Our middle finger is longer than our index finger on most. It then becomes the last finger on the ball and behind the ball. One finger determining the spin direction whether it stays behind the ball, cuts the ball, or pulls the inside. That can create inconsistencies.

The release with both fingers at the same time allows for less room for error. We typically will stay behind the ball creating good backspin, lift and added horizontal movement because the ball is spinning through the air better. This is compared to unintentionally cutting the ball or even developing too much depth.

For some, those are desired, for us achieving better efficiency and vertical break is desired for more swings and misses.

This is all attributed to having the middle and index fingers lined up - they can be close together or spread apart to achieve this. I have a image showcasing what the fingers together and lined up looks like.

This is extremely interesting and has turned on the 💡 for many pitchers.

I’ll be breaking down more ways we can achieve this soon!

Stay tuned and stay classy! 🤙

#baseball #pitching #mlb #changeup #fastball #changeupuniversity 

First video shot with @rapsodobaseball INSIGHT 👈

I always slacked at showing LHP grips so here’s one with a quick diagram of a starter grip for a CH.

Why do we want emphasis on our middle and ring finger when throwing a Changeup? 🤔

When it comes to throwing the Changeup, we want to lower the spin rate (or increase it based on spin direction), maximize run and depth, and decrease the velocity.

Our index and middle fingers are our strongest fingers, hint why they are used to throw our FB.

Our ring finger is weak and helps with killing the spin, drop in velo and spin direction.

As you can see here in the diagram images of the basic grip of the Changeup, emphasizing the ring finger. We won’t necessarily take our middle finger out of the grip, what is actually does is push the spin direction of the ball at release but in a weak way because we don’t have any pressure on that finger.

The ring finger slips off the ball and the middle finger will then swipe the inside of the ball to create more side spin. One 🔑 thing is we DO NOT want our middle finger behind the ball because it will then add backspin which adds Velo, lift and effects our spin direction. That is why I promote having the inside part of the middle finger touching the ball.

We want our spin direction to be around 3:00 on our Changeup which is true side spin. 

The thumb will be under the ball for control.

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

#baseball #changeupuniversity #pitching #pitchingmechanics #mlb

A key 🔑 feel in pitching is developing effortless velocity.

How is this achieved? By preventing yourself from “muscling up” or “tensing up” to throw harder.

Our ability to stay loose and quick allows for those fast twitch muscles to take over. Look at it this way, when we flex and try to move, we don’t move very well or quick. But if we stay relaxed and move in a controlled manner, then it’s quicker. That is the goal. Stay relaxed and controlled simultaneously.

This begins in catch play. Stay loose and extended while we throw further and further. This then translates to a flat ground and bullpen. After we develop a physical habit of this, it will then be subconscious and in game situations become effortless and trustworthy in our body and prep.

Stay loose. Stay quick. Stay elite. 🤙

Warming up and throwing with a football is a great way to develop a good arm mapping routine. 🏈🔥

This keeps you in the pocket and the ball is heavier which helps activate the body + shoulder + bicep+ forearm. It also helps break up the low key early throws that you make at 30 & 40 feet

Nolan Ryan nearly threw a football everyday. The correlation between arm strength and throwing a football could be extremely positive. 

A football weighs about a pound, so it’s about 3x heavier than a baseball. Though some guys use miniature footballs rather than NFL balls.

Try warming up with a football before you pick up a baseball!

A huge cue for many guys is the idea of throwing their thumb at the plate.

The concept of throwing your thumb comes down to the grip and finding a way to get your ring finger on top of the ball at release. Throwing your thumb is equivalent to throwing the “circle” that the thumb and index finger make in the traditional circle grip. 

The reason we promote the thumb is because not all pitchers can create the circle and we are already emphasizing the thumb under the ball for control. This allows the grip to slow the ball down and ‘kill the spin” as well as promote arm side movement. Now, does every guy need to “kill the spin” for an effective changeup?

NO. I actually love harder spinning changeups BUT we have to tilt our spin axis or else we create too much backspin which equates to higher velocity on our changeups when higher spin is involved.

This changeup right here was a quick demonstration that got 19.8 inches of run and spin at 2:24 for almost perfect side spin. (3:00 for a RHP & 9:00 for a LHP)

Try this cue and take the middle finger away from the center of the ball for less backspin!

I love utilizing the @rapsodobaseball INSIGHT camera for ways to visualize cues and pitch design/breakdown.

I wanted to highlight one of my guys who’s been busting his ass this off-season and leading into camp.

Zach McCambley has one of the best breaking balls in the Marlins Organization and out of any prospect in baseball.

It’s a pitch that was listed at arguably the best breaking ball in the 2020 draft.

Zach was kind enough to give advice on how he throws his and why it is so effective!

“When throwing a curveball, or any type of breaking pitch, a big thing is your wrist placement — where your wrist is at the point where you’re going to release the ball. That’s whether you want to throw it like a 12-6 type of curveball, or you want to throw more of an 11-5, or more of a slider. You can change the shape of the break, and that’s what I do. When I want to have more of a 12-6 breaker, I’ll keep my wrist a certain way. And I might be going for that strikeout kill. I may sweep it a little more laterally, as opposed to up-and-down vertically.”

“The spin has alway has been pretty high on it, around 2,800-2,900 [rpm] on the TrackMan.”

Velo: 79-85

“When I’m trying for a throw-it-over strike — either get early contact or a take for a strike — it’s more like 79-82, and then if I want to really go for that kill pitch, it’s more like 80-85. So it’s all about the shape and the intent that you throw with.”

That’s always been a big thing with curveball development. Presetting that wrist so we can get over the top of the ball rather stay behind it or through the side.

So much goes into throwing each pitch and we want to jump out and rush down the mound trying to create the shape and break of the pitch. That, causes you to be late and shoot to the side of the ball.

I’m excited to see Zach throw and earn his opportunity in Miami.

🤙

I’m proud of him and blessed I get to work with him and help in anyway I can.

What are a few things I look at in Changeup development with @rapsodobaseball data?

There’s so much that goes into pitch design because every pitcher is different. But I have a few baseline metrics I like to look at to see where we are and where we can go with the Changeup.

1. Spin Direction: This plays a big role on what type of horizontal movement are we going to get. The more tilt we achieve, typically the more horizontal movement. We can even conclude and incorporate SSW depending on seam placement at release. More to come on this!

2. Movement: The vertical and horizontal movement metrics are really fun to watch and play with. We don’t want to see lift, or a higher number, on the vertical number because we want our changeup to drop near as it approaches the zone. With horizontal movement, anything above 18 inches is a solid benchmark to show your changeup runs like a devil. 

3. Spin Rate: We hear “kill the spin” often. BUT, if we can tilt the spin, we can get away with more spin - which creates some deception with our FB. High spin, low tilt, we will see lift like our FB. This is no good.

4. Velocity: Is our changeup slower than our FB? This changeup in the video runs about 8.5 mph slower than the FB which creates good deception. This was a touch and feel bullpen so we may even see more difference with higher intent.

I love leveraging this data than helps paint a better picture for us mixed with feel and comfort. All, can enhance your game on the mound!

Developing a high efficient fastball is so tough. I’ve seen a correlation between simultaneous release of the ball off our index and middle finger to high spin efficiency.

Hundreds of fastballs thrown with athletes who use this cue and the average spin efficiency is at 96.55% 🤯

But Why?

Our middle finger is longer than our index finger on most. It then becomes the last finger on the ball and behind the ball. One finger determining the spin direction whether it stays behind the ball, cuts the ball, or pulls the inside. That can create inconsistencies.

The release with both fingers at the same time allows for less room for error. We typically will stay behind the ball creating good backspin, lift and added horizontal movement because the ball is spinning through the air better. This is compared to unintentionally cutting the ball or even developing too much depth.

For some, those are desired, for us achieving better backspin is desired for more swings and misses.

This is all attributed to having the middle and index fingers lined up - they can be close together or spread apart to achieve this.

This is extremely interesting and has turned on the 💡 for many pitchers.

But how can I achieve this?

Check out in the video of the position of my fingers. Check the release. You can see my distal interphalangeal joint flexed. This allows the finger tips to align! This is one of a few cues I will post and show how you can achieve higher spin efficiency!

Higher spin efficiency has been attributed in many instances to higher vertical movement which equates to swings and misses and a “rising” effect.

Give this a try! 🤙

#baseball #pitching #mlb #changeup #fastball #changeupuniversity

With the FB/CH combo, it makes life much more difficult for hitters.

This first split shot shows that.

Deception out of the hand and it’s trajectory until it’s too late and the hitter has made the decision to swing. The Changeup is already out of the hitting zone.

This is why understanding your pitches and how they tunnel one another makes you extremely effective even if you can’t throw 95+.

The Changeup, more so than a lot of offspeed, seems to be the most effective pitch to tunnel off of our fastball. Closely followed by a slider and other late moving off speed pitches.

How can I tunnel my Changeup off of my fastball? 🤔

This starts with establishing feel for your Changeup and the grip. From there, we then analyze HOW your pitch is moving and what needs to occur to make it better and feed off the fastball.

This attributes to maintaining the same arm speed and wrist positions for deception.

The analytics and numbers are just added variables to help design our Changeup the way we see effective. Does the eye test work in developing our Changeup to be effective? For sure, but it also only tells us part of the story. The analysis comes into play when we are seeing consistent lift, backspin & velocity making our Changeup ineffective. The analytics allow us to slow things down and see where we can make some adjustments.

All, help us achieve the goal of creating swings and misses or weak contact with our Changeup.

Having this combo makes you a very dangerous pitcher! 🤙

Unlocking Pedro’s Changeup. Part One. 🔐

I’ve explored countless hours of video on Pedro’s changeup and unlocking WHY it’s one of the most dominant pitches of all time.

This pitch was known to be a product of well-known coach, Guy Conti. Pedro learned this in 1990 at 18 years old when Conti explained, “By taking that index finger off the ball, you take 50% of your velocity off”. A really interesting take since we leverage our index and middle on the Fastball, our hardest pitch. Take one off and bring into effect a weaker ring finger. I’m big on taking the middle finger away from the center so that the finger can catch the inside of the ball to change the spin direction.

First, I’ve included some slo-mo videos that show how unreal the spin on his changeup was but also prove the dynamic attributes of tilting the spin.

From these angles, the spin looks to be the perfect side spin at 3:00. We don’t have the technology to read the metrics we have today. With this, we can conclude the arm angle + spin direction + spin helped Pedro create a devastating fading changeup that was 10-15 mph off of his Fastball.

Pedro has heavily explained his ring finger dominance showing how weak the finger is verses the middle and index fingers. Gifted finger flexibility and length, Pedro was able to get that ring finger on top of the ball mixed with “throwing the circle” as a helpful cue to get that finger on top.

All, helped Pedro achieve high arm side movement + drop to spiral out of the zone at the last minute. 

Another key is arm speed and deception. Pedro didn’t take anything off from an effort and mechanics perspective. He didn’t slow his body down nor his arm to achieve the velocity difference. He trusted his grip and the weakness of the ring finger to take off nearly 20% of his velocity vs the fastball. 

Is changeup development pure gift and genetics? Well, sure. You could say that about all things BUT it’s how we leverage what we have, how we throw, finger position and more.

More to come! 🤙

Unlocking Pedro’s Changeup. Part Two. 🔐

Jumping into more in-depth Pedro analysis on his Changeup.

What we saw in the first part was how Pedro’s Changeup spun and what we can infer about the spin axis which was around perfect side spin at 3:00.

I wanted to show how I can to a conclusion on the movement profile and how Pedro manipulated the ball the way he did.

After the spin axis, I wanted to see if I could find a similar spin rate without actual data from the early 2000’s? Well, sorta.

I took into account 4 current (Tate, McCullers Jr., Castillo, Williams) big leaguers who have similar arm slots and spin direction and averaged their numbers. Besides Williams, they all were around 1700-1900 spin rate with 17.2 inches of run and 6 inches of vertical break. 

Pedro seems to spin the changeup pretty hard but not in Airbender territory but definitely near 2000. This combination, mixed with ring finger emphasis, gave Pedro the big gap in velo verse the Fastball and the disgusting fade he created on the changeup thanks to the tilted axis.

From there I did plug in those metrics for a predicted movement profile and got this:

👉 Around 0 inches of IVB
👉 Average of 18-20 inches of horizontal break

Concluding that Pedro’s changeup was in fact ridiculous.

Tilted spin + above average spin creates some pretty goat-like flying saucers! 🛸🛸🛸

One of the toughest things as an athlete is finding a routine that works for YOU.

Especially pitchers.

I get asked often about plyo ball routines and warm up routines.

I give pretty boring answers. Everyone is different on how they prepare to throw.

Doing dynamic warmups and moving your body is 🔑 That’s pretty obvious. But finding in what order and which movements to do is the challenge.

Some guys will use a warm up written for them, some will copy others, some will do things that they like and what they believe will get them ready.

The main thing is consistency. Staying consistent in your routine everyday before you throw or whichever sport you play.

I guarantee these guys do the close to the same thing each time. It’s engraved in them now. The consistency keeps the nerves calm and the focus on high.

You have to do what makes YOU comfortable and prepared. Nobody else is out there. It’s just you. The ball. The mound. 

A saying that has stuck in my head was from my late and great mentor. He always said, “You better be sweating before you pick up they damn ball”. That’s exactly what I would do. I wanted to be hot and ready before I grabbed a ball. But that worked for me and kept me comfortable knowing I was ready to throw.

Most days that didn’t take long in the heat, some days it took more time with colder air.

But I kept things consistent.

Enjoy that downtime in your routine and most importantly, BREATHE and have FUN.

Is the overhead full windup beneficial? 🤔

Well, 94% of Hall Of Fame pitchers used the full windup🤯

First, some notable ones:

- Nolan Ryan
- Roy Halladay 
- Greg Maddux

This style of windup has seen some benefits for those who have issues with timing and establishing a whole body rhythm.

There are some that benefit from engaging their entire body throughout the windup rather than keeping their hands still and compact.

Some of the most notable transitions into the full overhead windup was @jackleiter from his freshman year to now with the Rangers. Here is what Jack told me about the transition:

“I really just made the change as a timing mechanism in my mechanics. I was occasionally tipping my pitches before based on my gathering point being inconsistent and going over the head helped create a more consistent gathering point.”

Jack made significant strides after transitioning to this windup which had him become the #2 pick in the 2021 Draft.

We see @thejoeryanexperience of the Minnesota Twins who has a notable windup and here is what he said to me about what made him go with the full windup:

“I started doing the “full wind up” just messing around and imitating Nolan Ryan in a very theatrical way. That evolved into a way to relax and clear my head during bullpens when I got a bit too mechanical. I was struggling with my timing a little and my coach at Stanislaus suggested I give it a shot in a full pen instead of just one or two pitches. I ended up using the full windup the next weekend and it has stuck around since.”

With over 90% of Hall of Famers throwing with this type of windup, does it make it the best way to windup to throw a baseball? Well, not necessarily. But it sure cooks up a great conversation.

It certainly can promote athleticism and the use of our entire body.

But the goal is to have our entire body on time so we can maximize force into the ball and minimize risk of injury.

Give this a try. If you have a hard time staying consistent in your mechanics or even tipping pitches - try the full windup. It could unlock a lot of things for you! 🤙

Pronation vs Supination ☘️

So, how can favoring one over the other effect your pitches?

So, a quick explanation on both. When your palm or forearm faces up, it's supinated. When your palm or forearm faces down, it's pronated. 

Check out an assessment that the team at Armored Heat test to identify whether an athlete is bias to one over the other or are fairly equal between the two.

We can assume, before any pitch is thrown, that Ben establishes a great breaking ball but tend to lift and stay behind the changeup making it flat, hard, and ineffective. (Ben has a disgusting breaking ball).

From there we can identify from a very broad spectrum what the pitcher’s strengths and weaknesses could be even before any metrics. 

I’ve added some slides to explain strengths and weaknesses in both biases as well as some videos to showcase this.

Supination biased pitchers tend to have great breaking balls but lack any arm side off speed.

In these instances, fingers at release, seam shifted wake, and grip orientation on the ball play big roles in creating arm side moving pitches. 

Supination favored is where you see changeups cutting.

Pronation biased pitchers tend to have great arm side off speed and fastballs but tend to throw a lot of backed up and tight, short moving breaking balls. 

With pronation bias, we can establish wrist feels and pre-set cues into slight supination out of glove break for example. 

Does this mean favoring one vs the other is bad? Not necessarily. But identifying which you lean towards can eliminate constant frustration with pitch design and development.

Most of baseball’s best pitchers play catch with their Changeup regularly. 

Here’s some quick Changeup catch advice ✅💡

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it!

We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count.

Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet.  We even see it with these Stroman videos and how the ball dies!

BUT, when you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont t to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers.

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

This exact thing was the lightbulb for many just to see their ball move like that. 

Regardless of distance, throw your Changeup consecutively and alternate between the FB too!

🤙

Two of the toughest thing to teach young pitchers.

1️⃣ Not tensing up to throw harder. Too many times pitchers tense up and try to throw harder which actually hinders our body from establishing fast twitch movements when throwing and rotating.

Stay loose but explosive and you’ll be pleased with how the ball is released. Teaching guys to throw easy beginning in catch play to long toss to bullpens will help with this.

2️⃣ Throwing right on right (or left on left) arm side Changeups. This is extremely tough to establish confidence in right on right or left on left Changeups. Too many guys are afraid their CH will run off too much on them and hit the guy or end up with too much lift and stay flat. 

Combining these two is picture perfect. Throwing the Changeup with confidence, conviction and with loose arm action. When we start to tense and choke our grip we spike it a lot.

This will make a pitcher extremely dangerous. A pitch that looks like a fastball until the last second to a hitter the same side as the thrower’s arm makes it extremely difficult to identify and hit when thrown well.

Practice this in bullpens with a hitter and establish the arm side Changeup in your arsenal, which is most typical for Changeup throwers.

#wbc #baseball #pitching #fastball #explore #reels

Classified as a sinker due to the high amount of run on each fastball.

Some would call this a two seam fastball since it had little drop (8 inches on this pitch). But he uses a 4 seam grip. Safe to say he broke statcast. 😂

But, to start an interesting conversation. Is it good to classify every running fastball under a “sinker”? 

For the general fan, maybe. For those heavy into pitch design and development, we can identify a metric that identifies this as a running fastball that doesn’t create much depth.

Per @rapsodobaseball - a two seam typically will on average create +3 more inches (13”) of IVB vs a sinker (10”).

Overall, this is why his splitter plays so well off of this fastball. Well, it’s also at 91-93 😂

Happy two seam Tuesday!

Here is a picture perfect, on the corner, glove side Split-Changeup by @stroman 🎨

One of the toughest things to do as a pitcher is throw a glove side Changeup.

I get on a high school catchers for calling glove side Changeups because young pitchers get themselves into trouble if they throw a glove side Changeup. Without the proper reps and skill, these pitches will tend to cut, which creates bad habits with our Changeup, or comes back to the heart of the plate and gets crushed.

We shouldn’t incorporate glove side Changeups in pens or live games until we practice them consistently. 

The level of skill varies as we get to higher levels. College guys should start to add these into their arsenal and pro guys should have the ability to throw a Changeup with conviction and confidence glove side.

Moral of the story, the catcher KEPT calling glove side Changeups and the pitcher threw the Changeup grip but the ball was actually breaking like a slider...creating bad habits in supinating pre-release trying to get that ball glove side.

The more we understand how to get the ball glove side that drops with fade we can begin utilizing this pitch.

I think this pitch is going to be huge for Stro as he continues to perfect the Split-Change to all quadrants.

I wanted to see what differences I could pull from Cease and Ohtani’s sliders, or sweeper for Ohtani.

Both were dominant last night and threw their slider/sweeper majority of the time last night.

Cease: 43% usage
Ohtani: 48.4% usage

So what separates the slider and sweeper?

Cease’s slider averaged…

👉 2947 rpm
👉 86.9 mph
👉 35.2 inches of drop
👉 ~ -2 inches of IVB
👉 3.9 inches of break
👉 30% efficiency (higher gyro degree)
👉 8:30 spin direction

Ohtani’s sweeper averaged…

👉 2497 rpm
👉 84 mph
👉 33.9 inches of drop
👉 18.7 inches of break
👉 ~ -7 inches of IVB
👉 63% efficiency (less gyro-like)
👉 8:15 spin direction

Both elite level, top of the chart pitches that get north of 37% Whiff over the course of a season.

On the final slide you’ll see a visual of what Cease’s looks like then Ohtani’s second. Small shift in efficiency.

What determines whether a gyro-like or sweeping like slider is dependent on what your other pitches do. 

Some guys just want a shorter action, drop right down slider and some really want the slurvey slider for it’s big and late break.

I have found that guys who don’t supinate as much and really throw it like a fastball and let the grip work create a more gyro slider. Others supinate like a karate chop and get more sweep to their slider. Both are effective!

Arm speed and hand speed are big key factors as well to maintain deception and develop spin. I’ll be making another post breaking down ways to utilize both of these pitch profiles.

I look forward to many more of these during the season as you’ll probably see them 1 and 2 on the RV with these two pitches. 🤷‍♂️

Check out in this video and how the Ohtani’s glutes and hips move out as the drift begins.

This allows us to get into our glutes where our power is generated. This is where our core activates and prepares the body for the energy to be translated from down the hill into rotation. It’s a great cue to prevent that back knee from collapsing!

Our goal as we release the ball is to make it effortless. The arm acts as a slingshot. The legs are when you pull back as power/energy is created. The letting go part translates to FFS and the most ion forward is the rotating of the hips and release of the baseball.

This turns into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

These guys all have that effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the core ➡️ hips ➡️ legs.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 💪

This is super interesting, and in the same category of a cue I’m looking into like front side extension. Much like front side extension, we all find a way into this movement differently so find a comfortable feel for you!

The legs are our strongest parts of our body, so we have to use them! 🤙

Q: “Why do I need a Changeup?”

A: The idea behind having another pitch in your arsenal is to get the hitter off balance to get them out.

Some may disagree with me but I’ve always been a believer in having a secondary pitch that moves arm side and one the moves glove side. Of course, a fastball too (4 seam, 2 seam, 1 seam, or sinker).

When it comes to the Changeup, too many young arms give up on it too soon.

I asked a player not too long ago while I was playing catch with him, 

“Throw me your Changeup”
“I don’t have one”

Right then in there we focused on the Changeup and by the end of the catch play, he had a pretty decent one.

We think there is one way to throw it and if we don’t throw one like a grip we saw on YouTube or whichever, it can’t be useful. That’s false. We all use different grips based on our arm angle, strength, hand size etc…

Your time is now to get a Changeup. It is never too early or too late. Having a deceptive pitch that looks like a fastball until the last second will make you a dangerous pitcher.

DON’T FORGET! Throw it everyday! Just because it isn’t “on” or you lost it doesn’t mean we should shy away from it. Throw it, a lot!

#baseball #pitching #mlb #changeupuniversity

#QuickChangeupTip of the day is a helpful way to to tilt the spin on your Changeup!

We’ve seen many different tips & tools to aid in this tactic. But many are tough to accomplish or use for youth to professional pitchers.

The key to this is keeping that middle finger away from the center of the ball. This allows the ring finger to be in control until it slips off the ball and the final finger (middle) is left. But the finger isn’t behind the ball, it’s pulling on the seam with the side of the finger like the image shows.

I did add in a video of Devin Williams release since he is across the seams but his ring finger actually stays on a lot longer than the image on slide 2!

Give this a try and see how your Changeup moves! Could be a gamechanger for you!

I’ve always been a big advocate for longer catch play.

Does that necessarily mean more throws? No.

But it certainly means more focus and more intent. We see over and over at the high school and college level of abbreviated catch sessions - mainly for pitchers/PO’s.

This becomes a “time” issue during a practice at those levels, when in reality, they hit BP for 75% of the that time.

It’s a joke and we need to appreciate and embrace playing catch with a purpose to prepare our bodies and minds. Each throw needs a focus whether it’s a breaking ball, Changeup or simply just hitting your partner’s glove.

We need PURPOSE. Robbing these young arms from finding that just to get to batting practice…

Carve out 20-30 minutes for CATCH in practice. Not stretching mixed with catch play.

Take your time between throws and focus. This is YOUR BP as a pitcher.

Many questions have been popping up on how to throw a gyro slider or sweeper slider.

Both are very different profiles but can have similar grips.

So what makes them different?

The gyro tend to be harder, shorter break, and drop.

The sweeper will be slower with a large break and drop will vary.

The numbers: MLB Averages from Rapsodo 

🌀 Gyro Spin: 2400-2500 RPM
🌀 Sweeper Spin: 2500-2600 RPM

🌀 Gyro Spin Efficiency: <10%
🌀 Sweeper Spin Efficiency: 60%

🌀 Gyro Vertical Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Vertical Break: -2”

🌀 Gyro Horizontal Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Horizontal Break: -8”

It’s pretty interesting to see how these compare. Spin directions also vary based on whether you’re a RHP or LHP.

When it comes to grip, this varies. But I do have some tips to help with throwing one or the other.

Gyro: index finger becomes the key. Releasing the ball off the index with less supination. I like to feel the seam between the index and middle fingers and feel the index pull on the seam.

Sweeper: middle finger becomes the key. More supination in a “karate chop” feel. Middle finger pulls the side of the ball but also slightly over the top.

Both of these profiles are highly effective. So deciding on which to throw does vary on strengths in supination (favors sweeper) vs pronation (favors gyro).

At the end of the day it comes down to comfort and feel and being old enough to throw a slider or variation of a slider.

🤙

#baseball #pitching #mlb #pitchdesign #rapsodo #slider

Why doesn’t my curveball break? 🧐

Breaking down how I throw mine.

A common question I’ve been getting…daily.

First, I want to state, we shouldn’t be throwing a curveball until we are old enough. Such as late middle school age too early high school age. Trust me, you don’t need one to get kids out on your 10U travel squad.

A massive 💡 moment for a lot of pitchers has been the pre-set angle of our wrist and forearm pre-release. We often are thinking fastball until the last second as we try to snap our wrist and get over the top of the ball causing for us to actually stay on the side of the ball or even under it.

One cue is to pre-set your wrist and forearm like you see in these videos and photos from the start. By that I mean before your arm has begun it’s motion forward. 

Some even slightly pre-set it out of disconnection with their glove and hand - be sure not to tip your pitch though.

This pre-set position allows us to be on top of the ball and helps our fingers pull over the top. This creates top spin which allows for that breaking action as the ball works against gravity. You can see the middle finger placement on the release.

This concept is just like throwing a football! 🏈

Or even a karate chop! 🥋 

Again, make sure we are old and strong enough to throw this pitch! So for you young guys, save this post for future reference for when that time comes! 🤙

These visuals from @rapsodobaseball play a big role in seeing how our pitches tunnel.

The first visual shows the effectiveness of a low CH vs a low FB. Nearly unidentifiable. This is why a low changeup is so effective and guys have a hard time picking it up. 

The second visual shows a higher changeup that moves well but added a slight hump vs a low fast ball. Plays well off a high fastball but more identifiable.

Are there times a high CH can be effective? Well, of course but there is more room for error with that. It could live up in the zone with no run or run to the heart of the plate. Good hitters can pick that up based on the hump in visual #2

At the end of the day, tunneling and setting up each pitch based on visuals and what the hitter sees can give you an edge.

This is why high fastballs setup breaking balls and vice versa so well.

Same goes for glove side FB and sliders.

We need to identify how our stuff moves and plays off one another.

Dig deeper into spin, movement, and more and you can create some nasty stuff!

A huge cue for many guys is the idea of throwing their thumb at the plate.

The concept of throwing your thumb comes down to the grip and finding a way to get your ring finger on top of the ball at release. Throwing your thumb is equivalent to throwing the “circle” that the thumb and index finger make in the traditional circle grip. 

The reason we promote the thumb is because not all pitchers can create the circle and we are already emphasizing the thumb under the ball for control. This allows the grip to slow the ball down and ‘kill the spin” as well as promote arm side movement. Now, does every guy need to “kill the spin” for an effective changeup?

NO. I actually love harder spinning changeups BUT we have to tilt our spin axis or else we create too much backspin which equates to higher velocity on our changeups when higher spin is involved.

This changeup right here was a quick demonstration that got 19.8 inches of run and spin at 2:24 for almost perfect side spin. (3:00 for a RHP & 9:00 for a LHP)

Try this cue and take the middle finger away from the center of the ball for less backspin!

✅ 40.3% whiff
✅ 18 strikeouts

#19 ranked pitch when it comes to RV/100 yet has better numbers overall than the number one. Also, his sinker is #2 in all of baseball…

The metrics:

✅ 1775 spin rate
✅ 33.3” of drop
✅ 0” IVB
✅ 18.2” of horizontal break
✅ 99% spin efficiency 
✅ 3:00 spin direction 🛸

Remarkable numbers. When I mention why tilting the spin on a changeup is so big, it’s because it drops our IVB which obviously creates more depth and drop + add in 18” of run and you have a filthy changeup.

His perfect side spin gives him that 0” IVB + 18” of run…just beautiful.

His tilt in ‘22 was 2:45 and this year it’s 3:00 with just 14 less TOTAL changeups thrown this year. That 0:15 additional tilt gave him 3 more inches of drop…that’ll miss barrels.

His changeup ranks #3 in RV/100 for CH’s, #1 in BAA, #1 in SLG, #13 in whiff, #1 in K%, T-#6 in Total RV.

Is this the best changeup in baseball? Maybe. This is part one. A few more top changeups will be broken down.

Stay. Tuned.

Check out in this video and how the Ohtani’s glutes and hips move out as the drift begins.

This allows us to get into our glutes where our power is generated. This is where our core activates and prepares the body for the energy to be translated from down the hill into rotation. It’s a great cue to prevent that back knee from collapsing!

Our goal as we release the ball is to make it effortless. The arm acts as a slingshot. The legs are when you pull back as power/energy is created. The letting go part translates to FFS and the most ion forward is the rotating of the hips and release of the baseball.

This turns into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

These guys all have that effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the core ➡️ hips ➡️ legs.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 💪

This is super interesting, and in the same category of a cue I’m looking into like front side extension. Much like front side extension, we all find a way into this movement differently so find a comfortable feel for you!

The legs are our strongest parts of our body, so we have to use them! 🤙

With the FB/CH combo, it makes life much more difficult for hitters.

This first split shot shows that.

Deception out of the hand and it’s trajectory until it’s too late and the hitter has made the decision to swing. The Changeup is already out of the hitting zone.

This is why understanding your pitches and how they tunnel one another makes you extremely effective even if you can’t throw 95+.

The Changeup, more so than a lot of offspeed, seems to be the most effective pitch to tunnel off of our fastball. Closely followed by a slider and other late moving off speed pitches.

How can I tunnel my Changeup off of my fastball? 🤔

This starts with establishing feel for your Changeup and the grip. From there, we then analyze HOW your pitch is moving and what needs to occur to make it better and feed off the fastball.

This attributes to maintaining the same arm speed and wrist positions for deception.

The analytics and numbers are just added variables to help design our Changeup the way we see effective. Does the eye test work in developing our Changeup to be effective? For sure, but it also only tells us part of the story. The analysis comes into play when we are seeing consistent lift, backspin & velocity making our Changeup ineffective. The analytics allow us to slow things down and see where we can make some adjustments.

All, help us achieve the goal of creating swings and misses or weak contact with our Changeup.

Having this combo makes you a very dangerous pitcher! 🤙

“Throw it off the middle finger”.

But what does that really mean in changeup development?

A few things come into play,

1️⃣ Grip & middle finger location
2️⃣ How does that middle finger create misdirection or tilt of the spin 

The first thing effects the second thing simply based on where your middle finger is relative to the center of the ball, regardless of seam orientation.

The more centered the middle finger, the more backspin we create which is why I get hundreds of questions on why my Changeup is so hard etc…

Shift the middle finger more towards the inside of the ball and you’ll start seeing the ball work.

Over the years the middle finger cue works and the cue to get the ring finger on top of the ball works.

Both pretty much do the same thing, it’s just how we feel or visualize it.

But throwing off the middle that isn’t centered and more on the inside will promote more of a forced pronation, but nothing too crazy unless you force it even more.

Play with middle finger location and get it away from the center of the ball.

This is why @tylerbeede has created a nasty changeup that has fooled hitters in multiple countries.

Unlocking Pedro’s Changeup. Part Two. 🔐

Jumping into more in-depth Pedro analysis on his Changeup.

What we saw in the first part was how Pedro’s Changeup spun and what we can infer about the spin axis which was around perfect side spin at 3:00.

I wanted to show how I can to a conclusion on the movement profile and how Pedro manipulated the ball the way he did.

After the spin axis, I wanted to see if I could find a similar spin rate without actual data from the early 2000’s? Well, sorta.

I took into account 4 current (Tate, McCullers Jr., Castillo, Williams) big leaguers who have similar arm slots and spin direction and averaged their numbers. Besides Williams, they all were around 1700-1900 spin rate with 17.2 inches of run and 6 inches of vertical break. 

Pedro seems to spin the changeup pretty hard but not in Airbender territory but definitely near 2000. This combination, mixed with ring finger emphasis, gave Pedro the big gap in velo verse the Fastball and the disgusting fade he created on the changeup thanks to the tilted axis.

From there I did plug in those metrics for a predicted movement profile and got this:

👉 Around 0 inches of IVB
👉 Average of 18-20 inches of horizontal break

Concluding that Pedro’s changeup was in fact ridiculous.

Tilted spin + above average spin creates some pretty goat-like flying saucers! 🛸🛸🛸

Baseball’s best pitchers play catch with their Changeup regularly.

Here’s some quick Changeup catch advice ✅💡

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it!

We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count.

Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet.  We even see it with these Stroman videos and how the ball dies!

BUT, when you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont make it to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers.

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

Regardless of distance, throw your Changeup consecutively and alternate between the FB too!

🤙

Pronation vs Supination ☘️

So, how can favoring one over the other effect your pitches?

So, a quick explanation on both. When your palm or forearm faces up, it's supinated. When your palm or forearm faces down, it's pronated. 

Check out a few movements that the team at Armored Heat leverage to help equalize supination and pronation. These help you get into deeper position’s and strengthen each!

These can also identify which one you’re biased towards. In a previous post with Ben he went through a test which showed poor pronation. Before any pitch is thrown, that Ben establishes a great breaking ball but tend to lift and stay behind the changeup making it flat, hard, and ineffective. (Ben has a disgusting breaking ball).

From there we can identify from a very broad spectrum what the pitcher’s strengths and weaknesses could be even before any metrics. 

I’ve added some slides to explain strengths and weaknesses in both biases as well as some videos to showcase this.

Supination biased pitchers tend to have great breaking balls but lack any arm side off speed.

In these instances, fingers at release, seam shifted wake, and grip orientation on the ball play big roles in creating arm side moving pitches. 

Supination favored is where you see changeups cutting.

Pronation biased pitchers tend to have great arm side off speed and fastballs but tend to throw a lot of backed up and tight, short moving breaking balls. 

With pronation bias, we can establish wrist feels and pre-set cues into slight supination out of glove break for example. 

Does this mean favoring one vs the other is bad? Not necessarily. But identifying which you lean towards can eliminate constant frustration with pitch design and development.

These exercises will help!

I’ve always been a big advocate for longer catch play.

Does that necessarily mean more throws? No.

But it certainly means more focus and more intent. We see over and over at the high school and college level of abbreviated catch sessions - mainly for pitchers/POs.

This becomes a “time” issue during a practice at those levels, when in reality, they hit BP for 75% of the that time.

It’s a joke and we need to appreciate and embrace playing catch with a purpose to prepare our bodies and minds. Each throw needs a focus whether it’s a breaking ball, Changeup or simply just hitting your partner’s glove.

We need PURPOSE. Robbing these young arms from finding that just to get to batting practice…

Carve out 20-30 minutes for CATCH in practice. Not stretching mixed with catch play.

Take your time between throws and focus. This is YOUR BP as a pitcher.

Here is a picture perfect, on the corner, glove side Split-Changeup by @stroman 🎨

One of the toughest things to do as a pitcher is throw a glove side Changeup.

I get on a high school catchers for calling glove side Changeups because young pitchers get themselves into trouble if they throw a glove side Changeup. Without the proper reps and skill, these pitches will tend to cut, which creates bad habits with our Changeup, or comes back to the heart of the plate and gets crushed.

We shouldn’t incorporate glove side Changeups in pens or live games until we practice them consistently. 

The level of skill varies as we get to higher levels. College guys should start to add these into their arsenal and pro guys should have the ability to throw a Changeup with conviction and confidence glove side.

Moral of the story, the catcher KEPT calling glove side Changeups and the pitcher threw the Changeup grip but the ball was actually breaking like a slider...creating bad habits in supinating pre-release trying to get that ball glove side.

The more we understand how to get the ball glove side that drops with fade we can begin utilizing this pitch.

I think this pitch is going to be huge for Stro as he continues to perfect the Split-Change to all quadrants.

A huge cue for many guys is the idea of throwing their thumb or “circle” at the plate.

The concept of throwing your thumb/circle comes down to the grip and finding a way to get your ring finger on top of the ball at release. Throwing your thumb is equivalent to throwing the “circle” that the thumb and index finger make in the traditional circle grip. 

The reason we promote the thumb in some instances is because not all pitchers can create the circle and we are already emphasizing the thumb under the ball for control. This allows the grip to slow the ball down and ‘kill the spin” as well as promote arm side movement. Now, does every guy need to “kill the spin” for an effective changeup?

NO. I actually love harder spinning changeups BUT we have to tilt our spin axis or else we create too much backspin which equates to higher velocity on our changeups when higher spin is involved.

Try this cue and take the middle finger away from the center of the ball for less backspin!

#baseball #mlb #pitching #changeupuniversity

A huge emphasis for pitchers is finding ways to take stress off the arm by utilizing the lower half to create effortless velocity.

This allows us to get into our glutes where our power is generated. This is where our core activates and prepares the body for the energy to be translated from down the hill into rotation.

This turns into effortless throwing. Loose is strong! The arm is just tagging along for the ride.

These guys all have that effortless throwing motion - as the power his generated from the legs ➡️ hips ➡️ core.

This movement is also similar to the way our posterior chain moves in deadlifting. Getting into the hips and glutes more to generate that power. 💪

A concept I’ve been preaching over and over is the ability for both, index and middle fingers, to release the ball simultaneously.

Why?

Our middle finger is longer than our index finger on most. It then becomes the last finger on the ball and behind the ball. One finger determining the spin direction whether it stays behind the ball, cuts the ball, or pulls the inside. That can create inconsistencies.

The release with both fingers at the same time allows for less room for error. We typically will stay behind the ball creating good backspin, lift and added horizontal movement because the ball is spinning through the air better. This is compared to unintentionally cutting the ball or even developing too much depth.

For some, those are desired, for us achieving better efficiency and vertical break is desired for more swings and misses.

This is all attributed to having the middle and index fingers lined up - they can be close together or spread apart to achieve this. You can see in the slo mos what the fingers together and lined up looks like.

This is extremely interesting and has turned on the 💡 for many pitchers.

I’ll be breaking down more ways we can achieve this soon!

Stay tuned and stay classy! 🤙

What do we want emphasize when throwing a Changeup? 🤔

When it comes to throwing the Changeup, we want to lower the spin rate (or increase it based on spin direction), maximize run and depth, and decrease the velocity.

Our index and middle fingers are our strongest fingers, hint why they are used to throw our FB.

Our ring finger is weak and helps with killing the spin, drop in velo and spin direction.

As you can see here in the diagram images of the basic grip of the Changeup, emphasizing the ring finger. We won’t necessarily take our middle finger out of the grip, what is actually does is push the spin direction of the ball at release but in a weak way because we don’t have any pressure on that finger.

The ring finger slips off the ball and the middle finger will then swipe the inside of the ball to create more side spin. One 🔑 thing is we DO NOT want our middle finger behind the ball because it will then add backspin which adds Velo, lift and effects our spin direction. That is why I promote having the inside part of the middle finger touching the ball.

We want our spin direction to be around 3:00 on our Changeup which is true side spin. 

The thumb will be under the ball for control.

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

Many questions have been popping up on how to throw a gyro slider or sweeper slider.

Both are very different profiles but can have similar grips.

So what makes them different?

The gyro tend to be harder, shorter break, and drop.

The sweeper will be slower with a large break and drop will vary.

The numbers: MLB Averages from Rapsodo 

🌀 Gyro Spin: 2400-2500 RPM
🌀 Sweeper Spin: 2500-2600 RPM

🌀 Gyro Spin Efficiency: <10%
🌀 Sweeper Spin Efficiency: 60%

🌀 Gyro Vertical Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Vertical Break: -2”

🌀 Gyro Horizontal Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Horizontal Break: -12”

It’s pretty interesting to see how these compare. Spin directions also vary based on whether you’re a RHP or LHP.

When it comes to grip, this varies. But I do have some tips to help with throwing one or the other.

Gyro: index finger becomes the key. Releasing the ball off the index with less supination. I like to feel the seam between the index and middle fingers and feel the index pull on the seam.

Sweeper: middle finger becomes the key. More supination in a “karate chop” feel. Middle finger pulls the side of the ball but also slightly over the top.

Both of these profiles are highly effective. So deciding on which to throw does vary on strengths in supination (favors sweeper) vs pronation (favors gyro).

At the end of the day it comes down to comfort and feel and being old enough to throw a slider or variation of a slider.

🤙

The glove arm plays an important role throughout our mechanics. Often, it can create some bad habits.

Some of the most misinterpreted cues in pitching have revolves around the glove side.

Our goal is to avoid that glove side to pull the shoulders early causing everything else to rotate quicker than desired.

You’ll notice in these videos that most of their chests are coming to their glove rather than the glove being pulled into the chest. There is more room for error when we pull into the chest because if we pull too excessively, the shoulders fly open, arm drags and we get ourselves into trouble.

This is why front side extension plays a 🔑 role in allowing the glove side to stay loose as the chest moves forward as the lower half drifts down the mound. Our hips will rotate initially then the torso and up.

Look what the glove arm does post release and deceleration. It stays in place until deceleration kicks in and the body does what’s comfortable! This shows the front leg has braced successfully and that our shoulders aren’t continuing and initiating the rotation.

You’ll notice as many extend forward, their shoulders are moving at a vertical angle rather than staying lateral. So if you look at a clock, they are more 11:00 to 4:00-5:00 rather than 9:00 to 3:00-4:00!

It’s an interesting thought to feel the front side be loose and allow the chest to come to the glove rather than pulling the glove to your chest.

Keep it loose & allow it to help with direction!

Gloveside changeups are so difficult but has Matt Moore mastered them?

Based on total RV, Matt Moore is #5 in changeups. He’s #2 in RV/100. A pitch that has potentially revived his career as usage is up nearly 20% (33.6% in ‘23) from last season. He’s never been above 20% in a season with the changeup. 

But when it comes to gloveside changeups, this is a spot he masters everyday. This takes consistent repetition to understand the way your changeup moves.

Do you have a ton of run? This is a tough spot to hit in fear that the changeup may lift and run out over the heart of the plate.

Moore’s changeup average run is 17.1” and drop is  30.8” with 2012 RPMs.

I’ve been looking at how effective high spinning changeups are to the gloveside due to the deception it can create spinning “like a fastball” when in reality it’s spinning slower.

For Matt, his Changeup spins only 300 RPMs less than his fastball. So the deception is there.

He finds a way to tilt it (9:45) and that allows for that high running changeup. 

A very underrated changeup.

I always had issues throwing a curveball.

I tried throwing one in high school, never did anything.

I tried in college, I would just spike it.

I always thought of “snapping” or “turning the wrist” right before release. 👎

So, what worked? 🧐

Reminder: Being strong and mature enough to throw a curveball is extremely important. Master the FB & CH before we tinker with any breaking balls. 

The cue that helped me was slightly presetting my wrist position after disconnection. Not too much because I didn’t want to tip anything.

That allowed my middle finger to get over the top of the ball to create the top spin so it could break downwards.

It’s a solid cue and may help you!

There are a ton of cues out there but getting into the right position before the arm comes forward is massive. Some may even think “karate chop”.

Let me what you think and if this helps! 💪

Make sure you are STRONG and old enough.

I promise you don’t need a breaking ball to get 10 & 11 year olds out.
