What do we want emphasize when throwing a Changeup? 🤔

When it comes to throwing the Changeup, we want to lower the spin rate (or increase it based on spin direction), maximize run and depth, and decrease the velocity.

Our index and middle fingers are our strongest fingers, hint why they are used to throw our FB.

Our ring finger is weak and helps with killing the spin, drop in velo and spin direction.

As you can see here in the diagram images of the basic grip of the Changeup, emphasizing the ring finger. We won’t necessarily take our middle finger out of the grip, what is actually does is push the spin direction of the ball at release but in a weak way because we don’t have any pressure on that finger.

The ring finger slips off the ball and the middle finger will then swipe the inside of the ball to create more side spin. One 🔑 thing is we DO NOT want our middle finger behind the ball because it will then add backspin which adds Velo, lift and effects our spin direction. That is why I promote having the inside part of the middle finger touching the ball.

We want our spin direction to be around 3:00 on our Changeup which is true side spin. 

The thumb will be under the ball for control.

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

Check the spin! 👀

Dane Dunning gets dudes out front on his changeup! 🙌

A 2:15 spin direction plays extremely well on changeups. The more we inch closer to side spin (3:00/9:00) the more horizontal break we can achieve.

His average 16.9” of run attributes to 1️⃣ Drop in spin and 2️⃣ Tilt in spin direction 🛸

How can this be achieved?

Many different ways but the most common would be middle finger misdirection or the swiping of the inside of the baseball at release. In most cases the grip and natural pronation can achieve this.

I can emphasize this enough…GET THE MIDDLE FINGER AWAY FROM THE CENTER OF THE BALL.

You see in Dunning’s grip how he creates more of a split between the middle and ring. A great way to avoid that middle from slipping to the center of the ball.

His grip along the two seams bring in Seam Shifted Wake into play where the seams interact with the air in flight and create an observed spin of 2:30. 🛸

Changeups aren’t easy.

There’s a wave coming and hitters aren’t ready.

“It just disappeared” is what he said. He was a lefty so facing Hamels was not fun & seeing the changeup look down the middle and then it’s gone and you swing right over it. True magic!

I still love watching his highlights, brings back memories!

A huge cue for many guys is the idea of throwing their thumb at the plate.

The concept of throwing your thumb comes down to the grip and finding a way to get your ring finger on top of the ball at release. Throwing your thumb is equivalent to throwing the “circle” that the thumb and index finger make in the traditional circle grip. 

The reason we promote the thumb is because not all pitchers can create the circle and we are already emphasizing the thumb under the ball for control. This allows the grip to slow the ball down and ‘kill the spin” as well as promote arm side movement. Now, does every guy need to “kill the spin” for an effective changeup?

NO. I actually love harder spinning changeups BUT we have to tilt our spin axis or else we create too much backspin which equates to higher velocity on our changeups when higher spin is involved.

This changeup right here was a quick demonstration that got 19.8 inches of run and spin at 2:24 for almost perfect side spin. (3:00 for a RHP & 9:00 for a LHP)

Try this cue and take the middle finger away from the center of the ball for less backspin!

A concept I’ve been preaching over and over is the ability for both, index and middle fingers, to release the ball simultaneously. All of these in the videos, besides Pedro before metrics, are high 90% spin efficiency.

Why?

Our middle finger is longer than our index finger on most. It then becomes the last finger on the ball and behind the ball. One finger determining the spin direction whether it stays behind the ball, cuts the ball, or pulls the inside. That can create inconsistencies. 

The release with both fingers at the same time allows for less room for error. We typically will stay behind the ball creating good backspin, lift and added horizontal movement because the ball is spinning through the air better. This is compared to unintentionally cutting the ball or even developing too much depth.

For some, those are desired, for us achieving better efficiency and vertical break is desired for more swings and misses.

This is all attributed to having the middle and index fingers lined up - they can be close together or spread apart to achieve this. I have a image showcasing what the fingers together and lined up looks like.

This is extremely interesting and has turned on the 💡 for many pitchers.

I’ll be posting diagrams on achieving this for those struggling to align the fingertips due to finger length.

How can you slowdown baseball’s top hitter in the postseason? Is it even possible? 🧐

Ronald Acuña Jr. is having one of the most impressive seasons in baseball history.

➡️ .337 BA
➡️ 217 Hits
➡️ 41 Homeruns
➡️ 106 RBIs
➡️ 73 Stolen Bases 
➡️ .416 OBP
➡️ 1.012 OPS
🏆 NL MVP?

It’s unreal he did this from the lead off spot.

So, is it possible to slow him down? Well…kinda. It’s baseball. 😂

What are some ways pitchers can attack him?

Digging through the numbers it’s crazy. Acuña hit .300 or higher vs EVERY SINGLE PITCH TYPE this season. The lowest BAA pitch: Changeup (.300) 😐

In most of these videos were he strikes out you’ll see the count has been worked to a 3-2 count. 

Going through his heat maps there’s very minimal weakness spots from preventing him getting on base. Because we can’t walk the guy out he’s taking 2nd and now we have to try to control that with only a certain number of pickoffs.

How to attack him:

➡️ Pitchers will have to TRY and get ahead and get him to chase. Off the strike zone, his weakness is the upper outside corner with 31% whiff rate + zone low of a .227 average.

He’s elite and your best bet is to either make him chase out of the zone away or pray he gets himself out. The Changeup is his weakest pitch so guys with great changeups, use it and make sure it’s down. He has 39 Ks out of the zone of his total 84 Ks.

Get ahead, pray he gets himself out, throw the changeup, make him chase. ✅ BUT good luck. 😂

It’s going to be extremely tough to slow him down but I believe this blueprint can push pitchers in the right direction. 

Or just take his @castleflexx away! 🤷‍♂️😆

All front side extensions are different. BUT the concept is universal!

I believe that the front side can allow the lower half to maximize energy and “catch up” with our upper half. We’ve seen a lot of guys who’s lower half lags behind the upper. They then use this cue to engage less of the front side and more of the core and lower half.

The front side should be loose and is simply a directional tool rather than a “Velo-Creator” 🔑

How to find out if that’s what you are doing? 

1️⃣Arm side misses
2️⃣Flat Changeup 
3️⃣Flat Breaking Balls
4️⃣Velo drops
5️⃣Yanking glove

Those are just a few things that pop up when you lower half is either ahead or behind. We must allow proper timing for both halves to compliment each other.

It is an interesting concept that could allow a lot of guys to fix their mechanical issues when it comes to the upper body. This is a way to unlock that lower half! 🔑

Baseball’s best pitchers play catch with their Changeup regularly.

Here’s some quick Changeup catch advice ✅💡

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it!

We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count.

Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet.  We even see it with these Stroman videos and how the ball dies!

BUT, when you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont make it to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers.

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

Regardless of distance, throw your Changeup consecutively and alternate between the FB too!

🤙

Looking at two unique, but similar, changeups.

Powered by @rapsodobaseball 🔥

The first changeup was the lower spin rate one. This one had more emphasis in the ring finger to create less spin and slightly more tilt. ⬇️

➡️ 1466 RPM
➡️ 2:24 Spin Direction 
➡️ 100% efficiency 
➡️ 6.7” IVB
➡️ 20.6” HB
➡️ 1.2’ Release Side

Changeup #2 had much more spin and less tilt and you can see the difference in numbers. For this one, the fingers are hooked with emphasis in middle finger away from center and really getting to the inside of the ball. ⬇️

➡️ 1876 RPM
➡️ 1:56 Spin Direction
➡️ 100% efficiency 
➡️ 11.6” IVB
➡️ 18.5” HB
➡️ 1.1’ Release Side

Understanding what metrics are most important for YOUR pitch design and development is honestly tough.

For the changeup, it’s a pitch so many throw away because either it’s not effective, no feel, flat, or no trust.

Think of it this way:

🔑 Lower spin rate with no tilt will give you slightly lower VB than FB but limited HB.

🔑 Higher spin rate with no tilt will give you similar VB and similar HB to your fastball.

🔑 Lower spin rate with tilt will be like video #1. High HB and low IVB. 👀

🔑 Higher spin with tilt, preferably under 2:00, will give you higher HB and lower VB than the fastball.

🔑 The closer to 3:00 the more HB & IVB near 0” with more spin creating more HB. 👀

🔑 Take into account seam orientation + SSW. More on this with @rapsodobaseball 👀

Tilting the spin is huge for horizontal break development + aids in lowering IVB.

It’s tough! But attainable with consistency! Finding a grip and finger placement + seam orientation can effect ball movement.

What do we want emphasize when throwing a Changeup? 🤔

When it comes to throwing the Changeup, we want to lower the spin rate (or increase it based on spin direction), maximize run and depth, and decrease the velocity.

Our index and middle fingers are our strongest fingers, hint why they are used to throw our FB.

Our ring finger is weak and helps with killing the spin, drop in velo and spin direction.

As you can see here in the diagram images of the basic grip of the Changeup from @45pedromartinez , emphasizing the ring finger. We won’t necessarily take our middle finger out of the grip, what is actually does is push the spin direction of the ball at release but in a weak way because we don’t have any pressure on that finger.

The ring finger slips off the ball and the middle finger will then swipe the inside of the ball to create more side spin. One 🔑 thing is we DO NOT want our middle finger behind the ball because it will then add backspin which adds Velo, lift and effects our spin direction. That is why I promote having the inside part of the middle finger touching the ball.

We want our spin direction to be around 3:00 on our Changeup which is true side spin. 

The thumb will be under the ball for control.

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

There are so many frustrating moments when it comes to developing and learning a Changeup.

We ask ourselves so many questions...

💥How should I grip it?
💥How often should I throw it?
💥Why isn’t it moving the way I want it to?
💥Why am I not confident in throwing a Changeup?

We all ask these questions. Especially if we are later in our career and development finding multiple excuses to not throw one.

It’s an extremely difficult pitch to master.

⬇️

The biggest things when developing a Changeup:

➡️ First off, there is no need to ever alter your mechanics for any specific pitch. Maintaining consistency between your arsenal will only make each pitch more effective.

Guys like @derekjeter could notice when you slowed that lower half down, or curled your toes on a changeup.

✅Comfort // You’ve developed a feel and comfortability with your grip so you can throw it with repetition.

✅Arm Speed // Throwing it hard to mirror your fastball and other offspeed pitches to create deception. Last thing we want to do it tip our pitches.

✅Fingers // Allow the fingers to manipulate the ball to create movement and drop in velo. This starts with taking the strongest finger (middle) away from the center of the ball and finding a way to get the ring finger on top of the ball as we release the pitch. A much weaker finger.

✅Throw it // Throw your Changeup a lot. Catch play is a huge moment where we establish feel. Many of the big leaguers I speak with about the Changeup throw it EVERYDAY. Long toss. Flat ground. Bullpen. Throw it often. We should do this with our other pitches as well. (I’d suggest not throwing long toss with breaking balls) 🤙

#baseball #pitching #mlb #changeupuniversity

Many questions have been popping up on how to throw a gyro slider or sweeper slider.

Both are very different profiles but can have similar grips.

So what makes them different?

The gyro tend to be harder, shorter break, and drop.

The sweeper will be slower with a large break and drop will vary.

The numbers: MLB Averages from @rapsodobaseball ⬇️

🌀 Gyro Spin: 2400-2500 RPM
🌀 Sweeper Spin: 2500-2600 RPM

🌀 Gyro Spin Efficiency: <10%
🌀 Sweeper Spin Efficiency: 60%

🌀 Gyro Vertical Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Vertical Break: -2”

🌀 Gyro Horizontal Break: -1”
🌀 Sweeper Horizontal Break: -12”

It’s pretty interesting to see how these compare. Spin directions also vary based on whether you’re a RHP or LHP.

When it comes to grip, this varies. But I do have some tips to help with throwing one or the other.

Gyro: index finger becomes the key. Releasing the ball off the index with less supination. I like to feel the seam between the index and middle fingers and feel the index pull on the seam.

Sweeper: middle finger becomes the key. More supination in a “karate chop” feel. Middle finger pulls the side of the ball but also slightly over the top.

Both of these profiles are highly effective. So deciding on which to throw does vary on strengths in supination (favors sweeper) vs pronation (favors gyro).

At the end of the day it comes down to comfort and feel and being old enough to throw a slider or variation of a slider.

🤙

Play catch with a purpose.

I’ve always been a big advocate for longer catch play.

Does that necessarily mean more throws? No.

But it certainly means more focus and more intent. We see over and over at the high school and college level of abbreviated catch sessions - mainly for pitchers/PO’s.

This becomes a “time” issue during a practice at those levels, when in reality, they hit BP for 75% of the that time.

It’s a joke and we need to appreciate and embrace playing catch with a purpose to prepare our bodies and minds. Each throw needs a focus whether it’s a breaking ball, Changeup or simply just hitting your partner’s glove.

We need PURPOSE. Robbing these young arms from finding that just to get to batting practice…

Carve out 20-30 minutes for CATCH in practice. Not stretching mixed with catch play.

Take your time between throws and focus. This is YOUR BP as a pitcher.

A cool sample of a grip for creating that high efficient fastball. I like calling this hooking the fingertips.

Align the fingertips and thing apply pressure into the ball. 

And yes, you’ll middle finger is longer to the knuckle will slightly stick up.

A concept I’ve been preaching over and over is the ability for both, index and middle fingers, to release the ball simultaneously. All of these in the videos, besides Pedro before metrics, are high 90% spin efficiency.

Why?

Our middle finger is longer than our index finger on most. It then becomes the last finger on the ball and behind the ball. One finger determining the spin direction whether it stays behind the ball, cuts the ball, or pulls the inside. That can create inconsistencies. 

The release with both fingers at the same time allows for less room for error. We typically will stay behind the ball creating good backspin, lift and added horizontal movement because the ball is spinning through the air better. This is compared to unintentionally cutting the ball or even developing too much depth.

For some, those are desired, for us achieving better efficiency and vertical break is desired for more swings and misses.

This is all attributed to having the middle and index fingers lined up - they can be close together or spread apart to achieve this. I have a image showcasing what the fingers together and lined up looks like.

This is extremely interesting and has turned on the 💡 for many pitchers.

I’ll be posting diagrams on achieving this for those struggling to align the fingertips due to finger length.

I wanted to highlight a few of my favorite features with changeup development on @rapsodobaseball 📈

Swipe over to slide 2 to see three features that I find extremely beneficial.

➡️ Spin Rate: Tells a good story on how much spin is being created with your changeup and where we can go from changeup development. The spin tends to be a large piece of the puzzle 🧩 on what we want to attack next.

➡️ Spin Direction: One of my favorite features. This tells a lot of what we want to do with tilting the spin. This is huge with creating lower vertical break or even more horizontal break, based on what our fastball does!

➡️ Movement Profile: How much is our changeup moving? What happens if we change this or that? This is one of the result oriented metrics based on the first 2 above. 

Think of it this way:

🔑 Lower spin rate with no tilt will give you slightly lower VB than FB but limited HB.

🔑 Higher spin rate with no tilt will give you similar VB and similar HB to your fastball.

🔑 Lower spin rate with tilt will be like video #1. High HB and low IVB. 👀

🔑 Higher spin with tilt, preferably under 2:00, will give you higher HB and lower VB than the fastball.

🔑 The closer to 3:00 the more HB & IVB near 0” with more spin creating more HB. 👀

🔑 Take into account seam orientation + SSW. More on this with @rapsodobaseball 👀

Tilting the spin is huge for horizontal break development + aids in lowering IVB.

I love the way the ball spins. 

I love how guys make the ball spin differently.

I really love this time of year to experiment with new grips, seam orientations, and feels.

What are some things you’re trying to add this offseason?

Let me know below and I’ll post some tips and tricks! 📈

#mlb #baseball #pitching

One of the biggest things is playing catch with our Changeup, which even means playing long toss with it! We have to throw it as much as we can to establish a consistent feel for it. The Changeup is a feel pitch, so creating that consistency makes us more comfortable to throw it in any situation and count. Often times when we play long toss with the changeup, we can make it the whole way, however far out you are. You are even able to get it there from 200+ feet. But, that isn't what we want because that means we are creating too much backspin on our Changeup. When you start to get a feel for the grip you want, it will kind of die before getting there. It wont make it to your catch partner. Same arm speed as a fastball, but it just doesn’t get there. Once you see your ball die, try to repeat it. This allows your to feel the grip and ball come off the fingers. 
➡️➡️➡️ That’s how Johan Santana described how he got his to be what it became elite. @thejohansantana 

I have even seen this when I’m messing around with my Changeup, it has gotten to the point where at 75-90 feet, it already dies before it gets to my partner. I’m also throwing it hard like my fastball.

A quick routine:

Start with a warm up (Arm Care Program)

- Start at 10-15 feet apart and gradually work your way to 100 to 120 feet. *Mix in Fastballs 

- As we increase our distance, rotate between your Fastball and Changeup grips. 

- Once we get to 120 to 200 feet, throw 5-10 Changeups at max distance. *Mix in Fastballs 

- On our way back in to complete our flatground, throw Changeup Pulldowns. Throw in a shuffle and throw them hard.

20-30 throws total Extend out to 120-200 feet (Throw 5-10 at max distance) Throw it hard with intent Finish with a flat ground and feel for ALL pitches Alternate between your fastball and changeup grip

Changeup development from different arm slots is the game. It’s challenging yet fun. 🧩

The questions I ask when developing from unique arm slots:

- Fastball spin direction and profile
- Changeup spin rate
- Changeup spin direction
- How does it come off the hand
- Seam orientation in grip

From there we can determine what we can tackle from development perspective.

Starting with the overhead release like Wacha. It’s going to be tough to create side spin so we want to emphasize playing off the inside of the ball as much as possible starting with the grip. This is where the ring finger emphasis comes into play. Keep middle finger away from center. His fastball is at 12:45 where js CH is at 2:00. I love that differentiation + the drop on spin (1522 RPM).

Logan Webb’s 3/4 slash sidearm angle is filthy. A heavy SSW guy with the sinker and CH. he gets 3:00 spin & observed at 4:00 🛸🛸🛸

It’ll be much easier to create side spin from the arm angle so we can get away with higher spin rate! More side spin = more run and drop. 

With the lefties, we see similar concepts. 

Ragans gets a little bit of tilt (10:00) plus drop in spin rate which is enough to create 3 more inches of run and more depth and a 5 MPH difference on off the FB. That difference plays at the big league level when you throw upper 90’s and can locate the changeup. Is there more in the tank for tilt? I think so, but like I said above, those higher angles are tough!

Sale has one of the highest running changeups in the game with an average of 18”.

His side arm angle allows him to really get to the side of the ball. Almost perfect back spin at 9:15 but he’s the opposite of Webb and gets almost no SSW. 

The numbers tell a good story but so does player feel and usage. We can see that lower arm angle guys will have an easier time grabbing tilt but how much are the seams interacting and how much spin is being taken off?

Those overhead guys have a harder time with creating tilt so many will rely on drop in spin rate to achieve depth and velocity difference.

There are so many variables involved. What are you trying to achieve with your changeup?

What makes their fastball create a high whiff rate?

➡️ Having elite secondary pitches.

If you look at their heat maps, their fastballs are dominantly thrown in the upper half of the zone while their next used pitch, elite secondary, is down in the zone consistently.

It’s pretty safe to say that the high fastball is a trend for higher whiff rates. Of course, having average velocity above 95 helps make it more effective but isn’t the only variable.

Having a high efficient fastball makes those other spots even more difficult to hit with that “rising” effect. 📈

What do we want emphasize when throwing a Changeup? 🤔

When it comes to throwing the Changeup, we want to lower the spin rate (or increase it based on spin direction), some need to maximize run or depth, and decrease the velocity.

Our index and middle fingers are our strongest fingers, hint why they are used to throw our FB.

Our ring finger is weak and helps with killing the spin, drop in velo and spin direction.

As you can see here in the diagram images of the basic grip of the Changeup from @45pedromartinez , emphasizing the ring finger. We won’t necessarily take our middle finger out of the grip, what is actually does is push the spin direction of the ball at release but in a weak way because we don’t have any pressure on that finger.

The ring finger slips off the ball and the middle finger will then swipe the inside of the ball to create more side spin. One 🔑 thing is we DO NOT want our middle finger behind the ball because it will then add backspin which adds Velo, lift and effects our spin direction. That is why I promote having the inside part of the middle finger touching the ball.

We want our spin direction to be around 3:00 on our Changeup which is true side spin. 

The thumb will be under the ball for control. Not on the side. Does not have to be directly underneath, can be off centered.

Our middle finger is the longest finger on our hand. It typically is the last finger to touch the ball at release. 

If you have the middle finger away from the center of the ball and emphasize pressure on the inside of the finger, it’ll prevent you from creating backspin causing the ball the lift and be harder. 

At release, our ring finger is off the ball and just the inside of the middle finger will be left lightly spinning the ball off the inside of the finger changing the direction of spin to favor side spin. Creating a flying saucer like spin. 

Give this a try when developing your Changeup 🤙

All front side extensions are different. BUT the concept is universal!

I believe that the front side can allow the lower half to maximize energy and “catch up” with our upper half. We’ve seen a lot of guys who’s lower half lags behind the upper. They then use this cue to engage less of the front side and more of the core and lower half.

The front side should be loose and is simply a directional tool rather than a “Velo-Creator” 🔑

How to find out if that’s what you are doing? 

1️⃣Arm side misses
2️⃣Flat Changeup 
3️⃣Flat Breaking Balls
4️⃣Velo drops
5️⃣Yanking glove

Those are just a few things that pop up when you lower half is either ahead or behind. We must allow proper timing for both halves to compliment each other.

It is an interesting concept that could allow a lot of guys to fix their mechanical issues when it comes to the upper body. This is a way to unlock that lower half! 🔑

I actually really like the position and seam orientation of this grip for the changeup. 👀

Being in this part of the horseshoe gives you a solid guide for creating some split between the middle and ring fingers. You’ll see in the guide how the ring is on the outside of the seam to help pull that on release.

But we know the middle will most likely be the last finger on the ball and with no lace to drag, it makes creating middle finger misdirection much easier when on the leather of the ball. The middle will slip off the ball at release to make that final push for more tilt in the spin direction. I’ve touched on this many times.

You can be in the position on slide 1 or like Scherzer in slide 2.

Both create a two-seam orientation you’re just not along the two seams like we see traditionally for many changeups.

Scherzer and Stroman which are used as examples for this grip create pretty low spinning changeups with Max at 1365 and Stro at 1778, though they classify Stroman’s as a splitter.

It’s a split-change okay. 😂

But test this out, it may just unlock a changeup for you! Feel is everything! 🙌

Could adding a pitch like a splitter or changeup change your career? 👀😳

I consider the changeup and splitter to be in the same family of offspeed pitches.

One example, Shelby Miller. Added a splitter in ‘23 while with the Dodgers. His 97% high efficiency fastball needed something to compliment it more than just a slider.

➡️ 36 appearances
➡️ 42 innings 
➡️ 1.71 ERA
➡️ 0.90 WHIP
➡️ 42/19 strikeout/walk ratio

By far his best season of his 8 year career. His splitter was actually disgusting in ‘23. Not bad for using it for the first time in season with 26.2% usage. Formerly a HEAVY slider usage guy.

➡️ .136 BAA
➡️ 30.7% WHIFF
➡️ 1:30 spin direction 
➡️ 2:30 observed so creates good SSW
➡️ 31.3” drop
➡️ 3” VB
➡️ 15.1” run

Believe it or not, adding the splitter actually made his breaking ball much better. He has a BAA of .208 with the slider where he’s averaged a .323 BAA his breaking stuff in the last 4 seasons.

My guess is he is a heavy supinated favoring pitcher and could never get a feel for a true changeup. I mean he’s thrown 22 total changeups in 4 seasons.

Makes sense why he resorted to a splitter. Much easier for supination guys and it worked! It also got him a pay raise of 2x for ‘24 in Detroit. 💰

We can consider this a pitching resurgence!

Spin rate in sliders and what does it mean? 🧐

I figured it would be fun to compare the highest average spinning slider and the lowest, respectively.

Here are the two you see:

Highest: Lucas Sims at 3002 RPM
Lowest: Ian Hamilton at 1512 RPM

So, how much different are they really? Usage? Movement? Results?

It’s actually wild how much these two use their slider. Sims uses his 50.6% of the time while Hamilton uses his 54.2% of the time. It’s actually unbelievable.

Visually, you can notice the difference where one LOOKS harder and late and the other is a little loopy.

Profile: 📈

Lucas Sims:
➡️ 83.8 average velo
➡️ 8:30 spin direction at 48% efficiency
➡️ 34.3” of drop
➡️ 15.5” of break 
➡️ .147 BAA
➡️ 41.5% whiff 

Ian Hamilton:
➡️ 88.1 average velo
➡️ 12:15 spin direction at 26% efficiency
➡️ 32.1” of drop
➡️ 1.1” of break 
➡️ .156 BAA
➡️ 42.5% whiff 

What do these numbers tell us? Well, both sliders are HIGHLY effective for these two guys. They both throw mid 90’s so there isn’t a huge discrepancy in velocity.

You could almost place Sims’ slider in the sweeper category based on his break alone.

At the end of the day, the higher spinning sliders will help you create more horizontal break and the vertical will vary based on spin direction.

It’s crazy. But for many, chasing RPM may not suit you or your arsenal best and that the guy at the top of the spin and bottom have similar results against hitters!

🤷‍♂️

Let’s see how unique these 3 changeups are that have perfect side spin! 🛸

We are looking at initial side spin knowing guys like Webb get solid seam shifted wake with their changeups!

Charlie Morton:
➡️ 86.0 velo
➡️ 2131 RPM
➡️ 36.7” of drop
➡️ 17.2” of break

Yennier Cano:
➡️ 90.9 velo
➡️ 1808 RPM
➡️ 32.3” of drop
➡️ 18.1” of break

Logan Webb:
➡️ 87.5 velo
➡️ 1476 RPM
➡️ 40.0” of drop
➡️ 11.3” of break

Out of the 3, Webb gets way more SSW than the other two creating an observed spin direction of 4:00 😵‍💫 just crazy! This also aids in him getting less run because once you go under that side spin mark you’ll get more of a tumbling profile.

Cano’s changeup stays pretty true the entire way to the plate (stays at 3:00 observed) and creates the most run. Pretty interesting correlation and makes since based on the tumbling that Morton will snag a little more VB with some SSW involved. He gets to 3:15 observed but nothing too wild to still get 17” of run.

3 very unique changeups that use certain things to their advantage. That’s what is so key in changeup development is understanding where you feel most comfortable on the ball and how & if you want the seams to catch the air to help with the profile!

I always had issues throwing a curveball.

I tried throwing one in high school, never did anything.

I tried in college, I would just spike it.

I always thought of “snapping” or “turning the wrist” right before release. 👎

So, what worked? 🧐

Reminder: Being strong and mature enough to throw a curveball is extremely important. Master the FB & CH before we tinker with any breaking balls. 

The cue that helped me was slightly presetting my wrist position after disconnection. Not too much because I didn’t want to tip anything.

That allowed my middle finger to get over the top of the ball to create the top spin so it could break downwards.

It’s a solid cue and may help you!

There are a ton of cues out there but getting into the right position before the arm comes forward is massive. Some may even think “karate chop”.

Let me what you think and if this helps!

#baseball #pitching

A big question I get asked, especially on the changeup grip, is do you have to make a circle with your index finger? 🧐

I have found that it’s not necessary. It helps take the index off the ball and shift weight in the ball but that’s only for guys with large enough hands to do that.

You can see in these diagrams that I let my index overlap my thumb. That has been a huge comfort thing for many guys I’ve taught. The circle seems to create discomfort especially with how it’s engaging the forearm.

The circle I always felt made the ball slip out so give this one a shot.

For metrics, I haven’t seen any real data that supports creating a circle. The changeup you see here averages 20+” of HB and 8.4” of VB with a 10+ mph difference vs the fastball! Yes that’ll very per athlete.

I hope this helps!

Staying loose & in control. 🕹️

So much easier said than done. Once we can train our brain to understand the effortless flow of our throw and avoid tensing up to throw harder.

It’s tough but starts in playing catch loose. Prepping the body to not be tight and restricting from a ROM standpoint.

Interesting enough I learned how that tension throughout the body actually starts in the jaw/face. Thanks to @airwaav for teaching me that and helping me understand how to avoid that whether it’s throwing, sprinting/running, or in the gym.

Effortless throwing allows that arm to be along for the ride while engaging the lower half, core, and upper torso. It’s interesting but soooooo hard to learn because we all want that “quick fix”.

Begin in catch play staying loose and effortless, then into bullpens, workouts, etc. BREATHE. BREATHE. BREATHE.

Such an interesting topic. 🧐
